title: PHilMech - Development of Agricultural Mechanization and Postharvest Technologies
description:
The agency conducts research and development programs, activities and projects (PAPs) to develop and/or adapt mechanization and postharvest  technologies and processes expected to improve  production, reduce quantitative and qualitative losses, with the ultimate goal of contributing to increased productivity and profitability for farmers and industry stakeholders. Science- and needs-based researches underpin the generation, development and commericalization of agriculture and fisheries mechanization and postharvest technologies and other interventions

To design and develop technologies that will address mechanization and postharvest technology needs of the farmers and other stakeholders in the agriculture sector
updates: The program consists of ongoing and continuing projects of which the activities targetted for each year of implementation will have been 100% completed at the end of the year
output: Postharvest and mechanization technologies developed and pilot tested under specific conditions of intended beneficiaries and end-users leading to commercialization; IPR patent applications

title: NDA - Expert Assistance on in-depth Analysis  of the Supply Chain of the Philippine Dairy Industry

Development Of Dairy Goat Products Processing Industry in the Philippines.
updates: Project is completed as of Dec 2018 based on OU focal person
output: Six (6) Dairy Value Chain Maps

title: Agriculture and Fishery Regulatory Support Program
description: The Department of Agriculture plays a principal role in ensuring safe and quality agricultural and fisheries products for consumers as well as facilitating trade of the same. This role calls for a farm-to-fork approach to ensuring quality and safety now being demanded by the local and foreign markets and consumers for the products they buy and consume. It also plays a critical role in protecting our borders from the entry of risks to human, plant, and animal health and life. It is imperative therefore that the regulatory offices of the DA must strengthen their delivery of services by recognizing and implementing reforms and practices aligned with the best international principles and practices.
risk: Procurement process
updates: The Office of the Assistant Secretary for Regulations of the Department of Agriculture is currently harmonizing the structure and functions of its Regional Regulatory Offices. The finalized Regulatory Framework based from the inputs of the regulatory officers is expected by the end of 2018.
output:
1. Provide a strong and reliable pest and disease control method by the use of quarantine stations and checkpoints for the early detection and emergency response to local and exotic animal and plant diseases that may cause negative impact on production, international trade and public health.
2. Provide an efficient web-based public service in the application and approval of permits
3. Ease of Business permit processing which is favorable for more business undertakings to thrive 
4. Provide standard guidelines for Registration, Licensing and Accreditation of agribusiness enterprises and other related businesses, including import/export sanitary and phytosanitary permits/clearances 
5. Monitor and maintain records of Incidences. Cases and Outbreaks of major plant pests and animal diseases and design appropriate prevention and control measures
6.Systematic and scientific prevention, control and eradication of economically significant plant pests and animal diseases. 
7. Quality and safety assurance of food of plant and animal origin 
8. Conduct periodic/regular inspection of food/feed products available in the market for quality and safety assurance 
9. Conduct periodic/regular inspection and monitoring of food/feed/veterinary drugs and products manufacturing establishments and facilities along with their counterpart animal feeds/diagnostic laboratories 
10. Develop Standards/Codes for Good Practices in Agriculture (GAP), Animal Husbandry (GAHP) and Aquatic Resources (GAqP)

title: PhilFIDA- Establishment of Pineapple Farms and Fiber Extraction Facility
description:
The commercial use of pineapple fiber includes its importance as a raw material in the manufacture of textile, pulp and paper and other fiber-based products. Pineapple fibers are also being used for other garments such as the knit wear which are exported to European countries by Nooks Inc., Ltd. while the handmade papers produced from the pineapple fibers by Cooperative in Labo, Camarines Norte in the Bicol Region are exported to other countries.

To increase productivity of fiber producers and thereby increasing fiber supply needed by the market.
risk: Non approval of funds, re-submission of proposed budget
updates: On-going implementation
output:
1. Establishment of pineapple farms and fiber extraction facility located in Camarines Sur,  Balete, Aklan and Kalibo, Aklan
2. To produce  raw material in the manufacture of textile, pulp and paper and other fiber-based products.

title: PhilFIDA - Provision of Agricultural Equipment and Facilities (PAEF) ( formerly Provision of Fiber Extraction Facility for Abaca Fiber Production)
description:
To enhanced fiber productivity, the Philippine Fiber Industry Development Authority (PhilFIDA) thru Fiber Utilization and Technology Division (FUTD) will provide support services to  farmers, housewife in the different provinces of the country by providing additional agricultural facilities such as Mobile Spindle Stripping Machine (MSSM), Stripping and Drying Shed, MultiFiber Decorticating Machine (MFDM) with safety mechanism, Improved Handstripping Device (IHSD), Stripping Knives, construction of Abaca processing center and warehousing for the production of abaca, pineapple, banana and other plant fibers to further increase productivity and sustainable supply of good quality  fibers for fabric manufacture, pulp, cordage and handicraft. The facilities to be provided are intended to be used by a cluster of organized group of farmers cultivating a total of 50 hectares per cluster.  The facilities will be provided/distributed to the farmer beneficiaries through cooperatives in coordination with the Local Government Units (LGU) of municipalities/ provinces considering  abaca, pineapple and banana and other plant fiber as a priority crop.  Initiatives from the private sector are also encouraged to contribute in the development of  these fibercrop.  The distribution scheme is contained in a Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) between PhilFIDA in concerned regions/provinces and local government units. Prior to selection of intended beneficiaries, criteria for section has to be considered.  The commercial uses of abaca and other fibers includes its importance as a raw material in the manufacture of textile, pulp and specialty paper, cordage and other fiber-based products. 

To increase fiber production  that will increase productivity of fiber producers and thereby increasing fiber supply needed by the market
risk: The project does not carry a major risk of not achieving its objective.  Adaptation of technology will be undertaken by a cooperative/association  selected by PhilFIDA.  Continuous training will be done   on the operation and maintenance of PhilFIDA-designed IHSD, MSSM, MFDM and other agricultural facilities.  Once the handstripped/spindle stripped/decorticated fibers are available  in the locality product conversion can be done by training beneficiaries which can generate income in the area and their product will be identified as One Town One Product (OTOP) in each municipality.  If there is a risk the  project implementer has already thought of mitigating
updates: Delivered 83 units of IHSD at PhilFIDA Regional Satellite Office  VI;  Conducted inspection of 83 units of Improved Hand Stripping Device (IHSD) and training demonstration on the installation and operation of the said device on August 27-30, 2019 in four (4) sites  of Antique with 100 participants in attendance.  Fiber produced using the improved device is highly superior or has a better quality than that of the traditional device. The devise can be used in high/elevated areas which cannot be reached by stripping machined thereby allowing abaca harvesting in highland areas. The commercial uses of abaca  fibers includes its importance as a raw material in the manufacture of textile, pulp and paper and other fiber-based products.
output: Improvement of fiber quality through Improved Hand Stripping Device, Spindle Stripping Machine, Multi-Fiber Decorticating Machine and  Sustainable Agricultural Development

title: PhilFIDA-Diversification and Expansion of the Abaca Sustainability Initiative  (ASI+)
description:
The project interventions were focused on activities that will increase certified abaca cultivation area from 0 ha to 500 ha at the end and increase average yearly income of abaca farmers with certification by 10%. Results include: 

- The production output of abaca fibres was increased up from 10 kg of fiber/day to 120 kg/day following the provision of simple machines that make it easier for the smallholder farmers to extract the fibres from the leaf sheaths. This contributed to the increase in income of the farmers. 

- A total of 36 smallholder farmers have been Rainforest Alliance certified on 149 ha of agricultural land (500 ha originally planned). 

The present strategic alliance aims to harness the results and lessons learnt for the diversification and expansion of the Abaca Sustainability Initiative (ASI), i.e. knowledge and experience are to be disseminated to new regions and firmly established with a view to achieve a broad impact and promoting structure-building results. 

Under ASI+, the approach is to be extended. The proven concept of GIZ's Farmer Business School approach will be introduced to promote the entrepreneurial skills and business management capacity of the smallholder farmers and their organizations in order to identify opportunities for enhancing their business operations and incomes. In addition, applied abaca research will be resumed, and the task of promoting resilience in the face of climate change will be addressed. The project approach will be extended within the Visayas region and will also be transferred to Mindanao.

Promoting sustainable development such as enhancing the livelihoods of the poor, using climate-friendly technologies and improving social and environmental standards at production facilities.
risk: Non approval of proposed budget
updates: Project proposal
output:
8 Fibercrop farmers associations/groups assisted: 
3 GLT (1 in Panay, 2 in Mindanao) 
5 GIZ (3 in Panay, 2 Mindanao - in close cooperation with GLT)

title: PhilFIDA-Development of Sustainable Abaca Industry in Eastern Visayas
description:
Eastern Visayas is among the top abaca producing region in the Philippines. According to the Bureau of Agricultural Statistics (BAS), abaca production in the regions amounted to 20,000 metric tons in 2011, making it the second highest producer of abaca in the country following the Bicol region. It also had 39,500 hectares of land planted to abaca in that year1. With the continued introduction of new applications and other significant uses, abaca strengthen its position as one of the major crops in the country with high export potential and continues to be one of the main sources of income among farmers in the region. 

Through the years, the productions of abaca were drastically going down because of the infestation of abaca diseases and natural calamities that hits the region. Several abaca areas are now unproductive because of slow rehabilitation activities due to lack of fund for this purpose. 

This proposal aims to rejuvenate the abaca industry in the region by rehabilitating abaca areas specially those already been treated under the abaca disease management project, to open new abaca areas, establishment of nurseries, distribution of farm inputs and capability building.

Increase farmers' income through increase in production
risk:
Occurrence of natural calamities and non maintenance of farmer cooperators

Conduct proper site evaluation and signing of memorandum of agreement between PhilFIDA and farmer cooperator/association/cooperative
updates: Proposed for funding in 2021
output: Six (6) hectares open-type abaca nursery;  Five- hundred (500) hectares new abaca areas developed; Six hundred fifty (650) hectares abaca area rehabilitated;  One thousand six hundred (1600)  hectares abaca areas treated; three (3) units spindle stripping machine procured, Six (6)  units fiber stripping shed established;  two (2) training of trainers on Abaca Production Technologies Conducted, One (1) training of trainers on Fiber-Based Livelihood Projects and three (3) Information Drive on Abaca Fiber Production Conducted; and  Tissue Culture and Diagnostic  Laboratories Operationalized

title: PhilFIDA-Enhancing Agricultural Competence and Productivities of the Indigenous Peoples of North Cotabato
description:
Indigenous People (IP) of North Cotabato remains to be  among the poorest of the poor despite the rich, abundant, & vast tract of ancestral domain lands. North Cotabato province registered a high poverty incidence of 34.5% in 2015. One of the suitable crops under these lush forestal areas is abaca which is traditioanally cultivated  by these IP's as part of their culture and a major source of their income. However, financial constraints of these IP's to purchase farm inputs and machineries hinders them to exploit the high demand and  prices of excellent quality abaca fiber which resulted to low productivity. 

To improve the socio-economic condition of Indigenous People in North Cotabato by harnessing the potential of their ancestral lands and maximizing abaca productivity.
risk: coordination  issues with LGUs
updates: With Completed Project Proposal and concept note
output:
Developed 4,500 hectares of new abaca areas
Established 9 units pre-germination nursery areas
Provided 72 units abaca stripping machines and 2 units hauling truck

title: Halal Food Industry Development Program
description:
The Department of Agriculture is one of the core National Government Agencies in Halal Industry Development Program as stipulated on the Republic Act 10817 "Philippine Halal Export Development and Promotion Act". the following sections are stated on the said law, below are the following:  
1. Section 10, Philippine National Standards for Halal - The DA- BAFS will play a vital role in primary and post-harvest foods standards; 2. Section 12, Export Promotion - The DA is one of the agencies that will support the DTI on the enhancement of the exports promotion;  3. Section 13, Infrastructure Support and Incentives - The DA also mandated to enhance the growth of Halal industries and assist farmers and producers in complying with the relevant standards on halal, the government DA also mandated to provide and/or upgrade necessary common facilities such as slaughterhouses, warehouses, refrigeration facilities and laboratories and equipment, in strategic production, processing and manufacting areas. 4. Section 14, Institutional and Human Resource Development - the DA will also a part on the development of Human Resource for farmers and fisherfolks such as Capacity Building, Skills training, scholarship program and the likes.  5. Section 15, Research, Development and Extension (RDE) -  The DA also assigned on the development on formulation and implementation of the Researches and Extension program.
updates:
Ongoing Implementation
Being implemented. PAP Title is change from "National Halal Agri-Fishery Program" to "Halal Food Industry Development Program"

title: DA-FPOPD - Farmers and Fisherfolks Database, ID System and Farm Geo-Referencing
description:
This project aims to create a centralized and nationwide  farmers and fisherfolks database that would support various levels of planning, decision-making, and delivery of interventions for the Department of Agriculture.  The database contains information on farmers, farm laborers, and fishermen and their farm parcel. The database can significantly improve the delivery of programs and services of the Department of Agriculture while making the data available to other agencies that share the same stakeholders as the DA.

It includes conduct of nationwide validation and registration of farmers and updating of the existing farmers registry.

This project also includes printing and distribution of  farmer's intervention card that will serve as a single and standard identification system for all registered farmers. The farmer's ID card can be used as a first level validation and authentication of DA beneficiaries.

Along with the ID card, this project will also provide a Farmer's Passbook / booklet  that list down all the interventions that the farmers can avail from DA. The booklet will also act as the farmer's own record book of his farming activities.
updates:
Ongoing negotiation with partner-agencies on the mode of implementation. The PAP has been proposed for funding under Tier 2 in 2019; however, this was not approved and included in DA budget.

Revision of the project proposal is ongoing.

Revision of project proposal is ongoing to be presented to World Bank
output: Farmers and fisherfolks database, National ID system for Farmers and Fisherfolks, Farmers and Fisherfolks Passbooks

title: Expansion of the Philippine Rural Development Project
description:
The proposed expansion of the PRDP with additional financing from the World Bank is critical to maintain the institutional momentum for implementing the reforms and new ways of doing business under PRDP.  It is also vital to sustain the unprecedented level of LGU support that has come through the devolved partnership arrangements under the PRDP.  

Given the fast turnout for infrastructure investments, the proposal to avail of USD 450 Million additional loan proceeds from the World Bank will mainly to cater to the excess demand and the prospective proposals for rural infrastructures.

Infrastructure Development Ã¢â‚¬â€œ this component aims to improve the links from production areas to markets to enhance the efficiency of transporting agricultural products. It also aims for higher productivity as a result of increased cropping intensity and yields, food security and improved health from readily available potable water and lower post harvest losses resulting in higher volume of outputs and more efficient support facilities.


Project Support Ã¢â‚¬â€œ this component aims to provide efficient and effective project management and implementation, establish a standard on services and technical assistance and effective mode of engagement with LGUs.
risk: (1) Project Stakeholders: The risks associated with resistance and/or slow uptake of the institutional reforms in the DA on which PRDP is built on appears to be diminishing as project implementation proceeds. The Project through the Local and National Level Planning Component will release a Harmonized Planning and Budgeting Manual. that will encompass planning & Budgeting, investment planning and monitoring and evaluation manuals. This will be distributed to all DA offices, agencies, bureau, corporation. others. (2) Governance of the Implementing Agency: The risk of governance issues within the DA and as they relate to LGUs in implementing the PRDP are increasingly diminishing as implementation of the Project gathers momentum. A high degree of staff, unit/bureau and attached agency support has been developed through active program of institutional and stakeholder assessments, workshop and briefings. (3) Social and Environmental: The MRDP 2 Environmental and Management Framework and Guidelines (EMFG) have been updated to ensure that PRDP  subprojects meet the requirements/compliance on Social and Environmental aspects.
updates: 17% Accomplishment
output:
(a) 16 regions with subprojects under implementation
(b) 81 provinces with PCIPs prepared
(c) 3,600 km of roads and 2,000 linear meters of bridges  constructed/rehabilitated

(Above listed items are outputs of the original loan and expansion of PRDP)

title: BFAR - Philippine Fisheries and Coastal Resiliency Project
description:
Component 1: Fisheries Coastal Areas Resiliency Planning (FishCARP) -supports spatial planning and developmental policies and guidelines. These may include activities relevant to integrated coastal zone planning focusing on Fisheries Management Areas (FMAs) using Ecosystem Approach to Fisheries Management (EAFM), vulnerable areas of the coast including fishing communities, and nearshore areas using the results of Fisheries Vulnerability/Suitability Assessment Tool (FishVOOL) conducted by NFRDI

Component 2: Fisheries and Coastal-Resilient Resource Management (FishCRRM) - supports management of coastal and marine resources to promote resiliency and sustainable fisheries. Activities under consideration include institutional and procedural strengthening of Marine Protected Areas and coastal habitats; management of fish stocks using modern technologies; development of coastal vegetation, and co-management of municipal waters with coastal communities, law enforcement and certification on fisheries sustainability and traceability

Component 3: Modern and Resilient Fisheries and Aquaculture Enterprises, Infrastructure and Support Facilities - supports modernization of fisheries and aquaculture enterprises throughout the value supply chain including investments on climate-resilient infrastructure, support facilities, system development, credit and insurance access, and logistics. Activities under consideration include development, management and modernization of aquaculture and capture fisheries; adoption of climate-smart production technologies, enhanced entrepreneurial support along with investment in post-harvest facilities, logistics, and improved compliance with manufacturing and food safety and quality standards

Component 4: Project Management and Coordination
The Project Management and Coordination will be set up in the BFAR will be responsible for the everyday activity for this program. It will also coordinate with various implementing agencies and NGOs, and liaise with the funding agency. There will also be an establishment of Project Implementation Units (PIU) at the Regional Fisheries Office that will oversee and be responsible in the field implementation of the activities. As the contribution of the recipient communities and LGUs, FMA Units will be created to coordinate activities with the PMC and the PIU. As a result, the effective and sustainable implementation of the project will be sustained.

title: PCC - National Dairy Herd Improvement Program (NDHIP) and Enterprise Build Up
description:
The Dairy Herd Improvement Program (DHIP) is sometimes referred to as DHI, DHIA, or DHIR specifically for large animals. This valuable tool helps evaluate the progress of the herdâ€™s milk production while addressing the improvement of the different production management system including breeding, health and nutrition. Through the DHIP, the breeding program of the carabaos at the local level will have a clear direction and its progress is measured over time to ensure that the animals are improving in terms of breeding performance. The DHIP is fairly inexpensive, useful and exciting activity that only requires constant monitoring and evaluation including documentation of activities.

In addition, the dairy herd improvement (DHI) system has a played a critical role in the advancement of the dairy industry.  Even today, it remains an important link in the industry. However, dairy industry changes, such as animal number decreases and shifts, dairy management advances, and on-farm economics, pose significant challenges to DHI. The nature of the dairy market, changing technology, and competitive pressures indicate the need for strategic planning and implementation among DHI participants, players and stakeholders.

The project is expected to benefit some 150,000 dairy farmers and 190 organized groups.
updates: The project has been presented to the DA-wide Clearinghouse Committee. The proposal is currently being revised for resubmission to DA Clearinghouse, and subsequent endorsement to NEDA. Since the project will be funded by ODA-Grant, it is possible that the project will commence by 2020.

title: PRRI - Expanded Capacity Development Program for Rubber Farmers Association and Cooperatives
description: With the recent technological advancements happening in the rubber industry, rubber stakeholders must be capacitated in order to address the need to increase production and be able to obtain a generous monthly income.  Production is not the sole problem that remains to be addressed, but also the low income of smallholders which is by far the rallying cry of every rubber farmer from now and then. Hence, this program aims to address this seemingly insurable crisis in the Philippine rubber economy.  Republic Act 10089 states, "undertake training and capacity-building programs for rubber producers, processors and cooperatives in order to increase production of quality rubber and raises level of income especially of poor smallholders." Given this function, PRRI shall conduct trainings/seminars/workshops to essentially capacitate the rubber smallholders, specifically the rubber farmers so that they will be alleviated from their former state of only earning meager income. Training to be conducted will enhance the knowledge and skills of rubber farmers in rubber plantation, and nursery and bud wood garden establishment and management, harvesting and post-harvesting of rubber to increase the productivity and improve the quality of rubber thus increase the income of rubber farmers.
updates: Approved Training Proposal dated August 19, 2019; ongoing PPMP preparation for the procurement of supplies and materials needed; Coordination with LGU in the nearby municipalities and other stakeholders for the possible participants of the training are ongoing.
output:
(1) 15 trainings on Good Agricultural Practices on Rubber
(2) 15 trainings on Rubber Nursery and Budwood Garden Establishment

title: PRRI - Leaf Morpho-anatomy and Molecuclar Characterization Of Seven Recommended and 2000 series Hevea brasiliensis in the Philippines
description:
Seven recommended clones  (USM1, RRIM 600, PB 260, PB 330, PB 217, PB 235, PB 311) and 200 series rubber clones that are utilized for large scale planting possess unique characteristics which are adaptable in different agro-climatic conditions in diverse locations. However, some of the commercial rubber nurseries which are not accredited supply rubber seedlings that are not yet identified. This is due to the multiple combinations of different clones without proper recording such as lay-outing and tagging. Unidentified rubber clones gives a detrimental effect in clonal purity and in result, hampers the overall productivity of rubber.

This project aims to characterize the seven recommended and 200 series clones in the Philippines through morphological, anatomical, and molecular methods for proper clone identification of distributed rubber budded seedlings.

title: PhilFIDA - Abaca Tuxy Buying Special Project (ATBSP)
description:
The Abaca Tuxy Buying Special Project (ATBSP) is the new approach to be implemented by the Philippine Fiber Industry Development Authority (PhilFIDA) in the production of excellent abaca fiber. This scheme will ensure the survival of abaca which is indigenous to the Philippines. Using a corporative approach, the project aims to organize and empower most of the abaca farmers nationwide as a cooperative, produce their own abaca fibers as a group which will redound to better competitive price, quality and quantity and sell their harvest directly to Grading and Baling Establishments (GBEs) and local processors. A group of abaca farmers with contiguous abaca farms for at least one hectare per farmer shall be formed into a cooperative with at least 100 active farmer-members and should be accredited with the Department of Agriculture (DA).  This project also aims to reduce the activity being done by the farmers to increase their productivity. The traditional way of abaca fiber extraction/harvesting by the abaca farmers has twelve (12) stages.  The project intends to lessen it to only six (6) steps --Topping, Tumbling, Tuxying, Tuxy Bundling, Tuxy Transporting/Hauling and Tuxy Trading /Selling --  thereby removing and easing the burden of the abaca farmers of the other six (6) activities and just let them continue producing all the abaca tuxies they want for the day before selling it to their cooperative that same day. This will surely increase abaca fiber production.

The project has an estimated budgetary requirement of about P20 million to cover the warehouse, stripping, drying and office buildings, equipment and facilities, hauling truck and motorcycles and seed capital for the initial operation. Feasibility study and logical framework was conducted and formulated thus, ready for takeoff once budget is available.

ATBSP is aligned to the newly approved Abaca Industry Roadmap of PhilFIDA. It is expected to meet the demand for the high-quality abaca fibers and uplift the status of life of abaca farmers most specially the indigenous people in rural areas.
updates: with completed project proposal, feasibility study and detailed engineering design
output: The project aims to increase income of abaca farmers who are members of an abaca farmer cooperative under the Abaca Tuxy Buying Special Project by at least 100%.
ppdetails_others: Detailed Engineering Design and Project Proposal

title: PRRI - Production Performance of Matured Rubber Trees Applied with Low Tapping Frequency at Varrying Levels of Latex Stimulants
description:
The cultivation of rubber trees (Hevea brasiliensis) in the Philippines is predominantly played by small rubber farmers holding only three hectares or less. With the unstable current market price of natural rubber latex, most tappers seek other income generating activity to augment the familiesâ€™ basic needs that solely depend on rubber latex production. Thus, the rubber industry is facing a scarcity of skilled tapper laborers. Tapping is the most costly activity in natural rubber production and the shortage of tappers is a serious problem in rubber plantations in the country. Low Frequency Tapping (LFT) systems are considered to be a solution to these issues by reducing the number of tappers required while increasing tappers' income.

Therefore, the need to improve the productivity and competitiveness of rubber cultivation is compulsory such as reduction of tapping labor and applying low tapping frequencies that may lessen the operational cost and can increase the marginal profit of rubber farmers. This activity will be compensated by the increase of hormonal stimulation by providing latex stimulant. With this tapping orientation, the profit of rubber tappers may increase since they will not solely depend on rubber tapping as their source of income.

title: PRRI - Nursery Selection and Seedling Evaluation Trial of Promising Ortet Clone Potential for Hevea Breeding in Zamboanga Sibugay
description:
Havea brasiliensis is a perennial out-breeder with a long lifespan which makes crop improvement laborious and time consuming. Breeding cycle in rubber extends to 20-30 years between pollination and yield assessment distributed over three selection stages. This justifies standardization of early selection methods to optimize and shorten the cycle as much as possible and one component of early selection is identification of traits at young age that have correlated response with yield at maturity and the other is combined management of different selection stages to improve the accuracy of estimation of genetic value.

This aims to determine the growth and yield performance of the ortet seedlings and discuss the observations on juvenile screening in Hevea breeding.
updates: The research proposal was approved last August 23, 2019. However, major revisions will be made base on the comments and suggestions of the panel of evaluators. Research proposal will probably signed by Executive Director before the end of the year.
output: One (1)new research production related and development activity conducted; Identified elite ortets in terms of growth and yield attributes that can be immediately adopted and potential for parental use for future breeding purposes;

title: PRRI - Screening of Introduced Hevea brasiliensis Clones and Hevea camargoana Species for Susceptibility and Resistance Under Corynespora Leaf Fall Disease Induced Condition
description:
Corynespora Leaf Fall Disease (CLFD) caused by a fungal pathogen Corynespora cassiicola is one of the major diseases which poses serious threat to natural rubber production in rubber growing countries of South and South East Asia (Edathil et.al. 2000).This disease is regularly causing more damage in any plant growth stages (i.e. nursery, immature and mature trees). Occurrence of this disease causes repeated post wintering defoliation that adversely affect the tree, resulting in reduced production and yield loss can be of more than 45 per cent. 

In order to keep the sustainability of quality rubber production, there is a need to have an efficient disease management strategy in modern rubber growing. Despite the economic effect of CLF disease-causing pathogen on commercially grown rubber in the Philippines, screening for susceptibility among clones as a method to improve the management of this disease have not been examined. Thus, this study aims to identify and evaluate potential susceptible and resistant clones and specie to Corynespora Leaf Fall disease from introduced Hevea clones and specie by inducing CLFD-pathogen to the leaves of seedlings of different rubber clones in nursery to determine whether clonal variation could be used to better manage the disease problem.
output: One (1) production related research and development activity conducted

title: PRRI - Mapping Incidence and Distribution of Major Pests and  Diseases of Rubber in the Zamboanga Peninsula
description:
The rubber tree is subject to a plethora of economically important pathological problems, mainly of fungal origin, the Basidiomycetes. Pests and diseases of rubber could prevent and reduce the full yield potential in the rubber industry. 

Limited information can be found regarding the distribution of termite pest and fungal diseases of rubber in the Philippines. Knowledge on the spatial distribution of these diseases in and among rubber plantations and on consequences related to disease infection or disorder and eventual latex yield loss is important to consider in formulating effective integrated disease management strategies. This is also critical in sustaining the rubber industry especially in rehabilitating senile rubber plantations as planting materials can be severely infected to fungal diseases present in the field or from the neighboring rubber plantations. GIS maps are one of the tools in forecasting disease outbreaks and estimating damage and consequently in designing cost-effective and location-specific pest and disease management strategies appropriate for different cropping systems in the Zamboanga Peninsula. Thus, this study will potentially support the lack of technical knowledge of rubber farmers on rubber production and management especially on the control of pests and diseases in the region.
output: One (1) production-related research and development activity conducted

title: PRRI - Utilization of Activated Carbon from Agricultural Waste Products for Natural Rubber Wastewater Treatment in Zamboanga Peninsula
description:
Rubber industry is an economically important industry in Western Mindanao, Philippines. The significant plantations in the Philippines are located in Zamboanga Peninsula. On the other hand, wastewater treatment is becoming more critical because of the diminishing water resources, increasing cost of wastewater disposal, and firmer regulations in connection to the contaminant levels in waste streams. 

Adsorption technique is an efficient process for the treatment of wastewater from various industrial plants. But this technique highly relies on the used adsorbent. The low-cost adsorbent should be easily available, abundant in nature, or a waste product from industrial and agricultural sectors. Agricultural products such as carabao manure, coconut shell, rice hull and saw dust due to its chemical composition such as holocellulose, lignin, and ash. Precursor materials can be activated using chemical agents (oxidizing agents) that will be utilized in wastewater treatment of natural rubber processing plants. 

This project aims to produce and utilize activated carbon from carabao manure for the treatment of water effluent from natural rubber processing plant	.
updates: The project was approved during PRRI Collegial review last August 23, 2019. It is still on its preparation stage where research proposal is under revision as per instruction of the panel of evaluators. Research proposal will be packaged and signed before the end of the year.
output: One (1) research project conducted on the usage of activated carbon from agricultural waste products that can be used in wastewater treatment of rubber processing plants

title: PRRI - Establishment of Budwood Garden in Rubber Farmers Cooperatives and Association
description:
Among the primary reasons for the slow expansion of rubber plantation in the country were lack of supply of quality planting materials, and low price of rubber products. One of the function of Philippine Rubber Research Institute (PRRI)  is to propagate and promote quality rubber planting materials, enable rubber industry stakeholders particularly smallholder rubber farmers to have access to quality rubber trees seedlings and showcase modern production techniques and other support services. With this project, it aims to comprehensively realize the goals of human empowerment and economic development in the countryside through programs and projects that will increase rubber production in the country and improve the quality of life especially in poor rural communities that depend primarily in this industry and to increase the available quality planting materials that are needed in the expansion of rubber areas.	

Specifically, the project aims to: 

(1) To increase production of rubber through distribution of quality planting materials that are needed for the expansion of rubber areas; and
(2) To establish and maintain PRRI Rubber Nursery in support to the distribution of quality planting materials to rubber farmer associations and cooperatives.
updates:
(1) Program proposal was approved by the Executive Director
(2) Initially identified beneficiaries however, it is still subject for site inspection and availability of funds

title: Establishment of PRRI Building
description:
"The General Administrative Support Services (GASS) program engages activities that support the day-to-day operations of the institution. As mandated, the GASS under the PRRI will provide general administrative support across the natural rubber research and development program of PRRI.

The building will be located in Naga, Zamboanga Sibugay, a municipality with vast area planted with rubber trees, making it a strategic location for conduct of rubber research. Necessary facilities are needed to be set up in order to fully materialize the goal of PRRI. Thus, this PRRI building will be established with different testing laboratories to aid in the research needs and requests from the rubber stakeholders for testing. The laboratories are the following: pest control laboratory, rubber testing laboratory, soil testing laboratory, and genetics laboratory. This will also house the different divisions of the agency: Rubber Technology and Extension Division (RTESD), Crop Management Division (CMD), Genetics Resources Improvement Division (GRID), Office of the Executive Director (OED). Conference room, audio visual room, electric room and ICT room, and dormitory will also form part of the building.
risk:
Implementation Risks: delay completion from the target completion date on the establishment of the building;

Mitigation Strategies: a MOA will be signed between PRRI and the contractor to determine the consequences if the target completion date will note be pursued.
output: Establishment of one (1) PRRI Office Building

title: PRRI - Establishment of PRRI Laboratories and Shared Facilities
description:
The PRRI is mandated to consolidate, coordinate and strengthen the national rubber research and development program, while serving as the nerve center for plantation expansion and training activities for rubber producers, processors, and rubber product manufacturers. RA 10089 provides that the PRRIâ€™s integral role in providing an enabling mechanism for technology development and incubation and eventually its diffusion into the natural rubber industry stakeholders in the upstream and downstream sectors.

With this, there is the immediate need to put up the shared facilities and laboratories. The shared facilities will consist of a dormitory, training center and museum while the laboratories will consist of soil, molecular, pest and disease diagnostic, rubber testing and tissue culture laboratory.

The project leads to strengthen the implementation of research and development activities, enhance the current rubber production for adaptation of rubber farmers, develop new technology to increase the rubber production in the country and enhanced  the development of technical expertise of rubber R&D/E workers.
risk:
Implementation Risks: late release of funds; delay procurement of equipment and materials; project slippage

Mitigation Strategies: close coordination with the Chinese Ministry of Agriculture and PRRI Finance staff for the update on the requested budget; pre-procurement will be done on the prior year of implementation; Memorandum of Agreement will be drafted and signed with the contracting agency to ensure target completion date will be achieved
updates:
(1) Presented during 6th Joint Committee meeting on Agriculture
(2) On-going project proposal evaluation by the DA Clearing House
output:
(1) Established and operationalized shared facilities and laboratories
(2) 5 laboratories, 1 dormitory, 1 training center and 1 rubber museum will be established

title: PhilFIDA - Construction of 4-storey building in Quezon City
description:
The Philippine Fiber Industry Development Authority, known today as a PhP7B-industry doesn't have its own  Central Office building until this time. Since the creation of the original Fiber Industry  Development Authority (FIDA) in July 1981 until it was consolidated with the Cotton Development Authority (CODA) into Philippine Fiber Industry Development Authority (PhilFIDA) on May 2013, the agency has been renting office spaces for 32 years wherein the government  spent about P170M as rental payment.  This amount excludes the   hauling and other logistics cost for the transferring which has gone 6x (6 buildings in the span of 32 years).  By this, the agency also has to spend substantial amount on renting training/seminar venues.  Since Nov. 2015, the agency is housed in the portion of the 3rd Floor of DA-PCAF Bldg. but there is an advisory that PhilFIDA has to vacate the place because it will be utilized by DA. 

The proposed  4-storey building will serve as PhilFIDA Central Office Administrative Office with training facilities and dormitory.
risk:
Occurrence of heavy rains during the concreting phase.
Awareness of the weather forecast and apply proper scheduling.
updates: with a project proposal and feasibility study
output: Four (4) storey building for Central Office, Quezon city constructed

title: PhilFIDA - PhilFIDA ICT Project
description:
Technical assistance and advisory services, information, education and communication support services for farmersâ€™ groups and agricultural technicians of the Local Government Units (LGUs) and training services are among those banner programs of PhilFIDA. Information needed in the implementation of these programs is dispersed to all provincial and regional offices. Obtaining such information from one office to another may cause some difficulty and a possible duplication of efforts in maintaining similar systems and/or databases across different field offices occurs due to the geographical concerns. Obviously, there is a need to integrate information sources and build-up an agency-wide knowledge databank and up-to-date web portal to ensure easy access to updated, relevant and timely information. Improvement of electronic links within the organization as well as with the other external entities is also necessary. 

Data and information systems on the geographical location of programs and projects of the agency presented in electronic maps are also needed to be developed for effective monitoring and to reduce the need for clients to physically go to PhilFIDA offices to avail of services or obtain the information they need. An improved internal system can be better delivered through the use of latest technologies on intranet and extranet solutions, particularly through web-enabled applications.

Voice and data communication technologies can manage coordinative works between central office and different provincial and regional offices. Centralized system within the agency will further enhance productivity through web-enabled applications.

The ISSP aims to guide PhilFIDA in the implementation of its ICT initiatives and projects to enhance its performance and achieve its goals. This also includes the proposed ICT organizational structure to cope with changing requirements and fast-paced technology.

This ISSP covers the Central Office, Laboratories, Experimental Stations and all Regional and Provincial Offices of PhilFIDA.
risk: Non-approval of  proposed funds, hence, approval of proposed funds
updates: Complete packaged of proposal with Plans and Design for Infrastructure.
output: The project aims to modernized the processes of the agency in the performance of its functions. Support to operation by providing ICT equipment, device and paraphernalia to fast track the performance of the activities.

title: BFAR - Integrated Marine Environment Monitoring System - Phase 3 (IMEMS)
description:
The complete IMEMS system which comprises of Phases I, II & III will provide DA-BFAR with a powerful and fully integrated fisheries, marine environment & aquatic life management and monitoring system which covers the entire Philippine fishing industry. IMEMS III will extend the existing IMEMS system to include the monitoring of all commercial and municipal vessels operating in Philippine waters, and thus result in a single integrated system that manages and monitors all Philippine fishing vessels.

The project aims to significantly improve and extend the existing capabilities of the BFAR Vessel Monitoring System (VMS) and operationalize a Single Integrated National Marine Environment Monitoring System that is financially viable and scalable over the long term.
risk:

Mitigation Strategy: BFAR to make sure that electric power supply is available on a permanent basis, using appropriate UPS, genset for the continuation of operations."
updates: With project proposal
output: Single Integrated National Marine Environment Monitoring System for both commercial and municipal vessels established and operationalized.
